metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: Standard deviation is a number that describes how spread out the observations are.
content.html: Standard deviation is a number that describes how spread out the observations are.

content.text: A mathematical function will have difficulties in predicting precise values, if the observations are "spread". Standard deviation is a measure of uncertainty.
content.html: A mathematical function will have difficulties in predicting precise values, if the observations are "spread". Standard deviation is a measure of uncertainty.

content.text: A low standard deviation means that most of the numbers are close to the mean (average) value.
content.html: A low standard deviation means that most of the numbers are close to the mean (average) value.

content.text: A high standard deviation means that the values are spread out over a wider range.
content.html: A high standard deviation means that the values are spread out over a wider range.

content.text: Tip: Standard Deviation is often represented by the symbol Sigma: σ
content.html: Tip: Standard Deviation is often represented by the symbol Sigma: σ

content.text: We can use the std() function from Numpy to find the standard deviation of a variable:
content.html: We can use the std() function from Numpy to find the standard deviation of a variable:

content.code_html:
import numpy as np

std = np.std(full_health_data)
print(std)

content.text: The coefficient of variation is used to get an idea of how large the standard deviation is.
content.html: The coefficient of variation is used to get an idea of how large the standard deviation is.

content.text: Mathematically, the coefficient of variation is defined as:
content.html: Mathematically, the coefficient of variation is defined as:

content.code_html: Coefficient of Variation = Standard Deviation / Mean

content.text: We can do this in Python if we proceed with the following code:
content.html: We can do this in Python if we proceed with the following code:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
import numpy as npcv = np.std(full_health_data) / np.mean(full_health_data)
  print(cv)

content.code:
import numpy as npcv = np.std(full_health_data) / np.mean(full_health_data)
print(cv)

syntax_highlighting.text:
import numpy as npcv = np.std(full_health_data) / np.mean(full_health_data)
 print(cv)

content.code_html:
import numpy as np

cv = np.std(full_health_data) / np.mean(full_health_data)
print(cv)

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
import numpy as npcv = np.std(full_health_data) / np.mean(full_health_data)
  print(cv)

content.text: We see that the variables Duration, Calorie_Burnage and Hours_Work has a high Standard Deviation compared to Max_Pulse, Average_Pulse and Hours_Sleep.
content.html: We see that the variables Duration, Calorie_Burnage and Hours_Work has a high Standard Deviation compared to Max_Pulse, Average_Pulse and Hours_Sleep.
